title: Top Drugs Final Mock B — 88 Questions

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Stimulates alpha-2 receptors in the brainstem, reducing sympathetic outflow and lowering blood pressure.
answer: Catapres

choices: Inhibits calcium influx into vascular and cardiac muscle; reduces heart rate and contractility.
Inhibits sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule, increasing excretion of sodium and water.
Selectively blocks angiotensin II at the AT1 receptor, reducing vasoconstriction.
Nonselectively blocks beta receptors with additional alpha-blockade; reduces heart rate and peripheral resistance.
answer: Inhibits calcium influx into vascular and cardiac muscle; reduces heart rate and contractility.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, reducing cholesterol synthesis and increasing LDL uptake.
answer: Crestor

choices: Inhibits PCSK9 protein to prevent LDL receptor degradation (monoclonal antibody).
Inhibits cholesterol absorption at the brush border of the small intestine.
Activates PPAR-alpha, increasing lipolysis of triglyceride-rich particles.
Inhibits PCSK9 synthesis via RNA interference, increasing LDL receptor availability.
answer: Inhibits PCSK9 protein to prevent LDL receptor degradation (monoclonal antibody).

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Inhibits synthesis of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.
answer: Coumadin

choices: Enhances antithrombin III activity to inhibit thrombin and Factor Xa.
Directly inhibits Factor Xa, preventing conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.
Inhibits platelet P2Y12 receptor to prevent aggregation.
answer: Enhances antithrombin III activity to inhibit thrombin and Factor Xa.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Nonselectively blocks beta receptors and inhibits potassium channels; prolongs action potential and refractory period.
answer: Betapace

choices: Inhibits potassium channels; prolongs action potential and refractory period of cardiac cells.
Blocks sodium channels; decreases conduction in ischemic and depolarized cells.
Inhibits calcium influx into cardiac muscle; reduces AV nodal conduction.
Directly stimulates beta-1 receptors to increase inotropy.
answer: Inhibits potassium channels; prolongs action potential and refractory period of cardiac cells.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Basal insulin regulating glucose metabolism.
answer: Lantus

choices: Decreases hepatic glucose production; decreases intestinal glucose absorption; improves insulin sensitivity.
Inhibits DPP-4, increasing incretin levels and glucose-dependent insulin secretion.
Inhibits SGLT2 in the proximal renal tubules, reducing glucose reabsorption.
Stimulates pancreatic beta cells by blocking ATP-sensitive potassium channels to increase insulin release.
answer: Decreases hepatic glucose production; decreases intestinal glucose absorption; improves insulin sensitivity.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Dual GIP/GLP-1 receptor agonist; enhances glucose-dependent insulin and reduces glucagon.
answer: Zepbound

choices: Inhibits DPP-4, increasing incretin levels and glucose-dependent insulin secretion.
Activates GLP-1 receptor; increases glucose-dependent insulin; decreases inappropriate glucagon.
Increases insulin sensitivity by activating PPAR-gamma.
Inhibits SGLT2 in the proximal renal tubules, reducing glucose reabsorption.
answer: Inhibits DPP-4, increasing incretin levels and glucose-dependent insulin secretion.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Stimulates pancreatic beta cells by blocking ATP-sensitive potassium channels to increase insulin release.
answer: Amaryl

choices: Inhibits SGLT2 in the proximal renal tubules to reduce glucose reabsorption.
Inhibits DPP-4, increasing incretin levels and glucose-dependent insulin secretion.
Increases insulin sensitivity by activating PPAR-gamma.
Activates GLP-1 receptor; increases glucose-dependent insulin; decreases inappropriate glucagon.
answer: Inhibits SGLT2 in the proximal renal tubules to reduce glucose reabsorption.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Enhances GABA-mediated inhibition via benzodiazepine receptor complex.
answer: Ambien

choices: Blocks voltage-dependent sodium channels; enhances GABA(A); antagonizes AMPA/kainate; weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.
Stabilizes neuronal membranes and modulates release of excitatory neurotransmitters.
Inhibits voltage-dependent N-type calcium channels; facilitates GABAergic inhibition; binds synaptic proteins to modulate release.
Enhances GABA-mediated inhibition via benzodiazepine receptor complex.
answer: Blocks voltage-dependent sodium channels; enhances GABA(A); antagonizes AMPA/kainate; weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Increases dopamine release in the brain by blocking alpha-2-adrenergic and 5-HT2C receptors.
answer: Remeron

choices: Inhibits reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, increasing their levels.
Selectively inhibits serotonin reuptake, increasing serotonin levels in the synaptic cleft.
Inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, increasing their levels.
answer: Inhibits reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, increasing their levels.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Partial agonist at dopamine D2 and 5-HT1A; antagonist at 5-HT2A receptors.
answer: Abilify

choices: Antagonizes dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2 receptors, producing antipsychotic effects.
Increases dopamine release by alpha-2 blockade and 5-HT2C blockade.
answer: Antagonizes dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2 receptors, producing antipsychotic effects.

easy.prompt: Which drug has this mechanism? Largely unknown; high affinity for 5-HT1A and 5-HT2 receptors; does not affect benzodiazepine-GABA receptors.
answer: Bucapsol

choices: Benzodiazepine; enhances GABA effects at the receptor complex.
Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels in motor cortex neurons.
answer: Benzodiazepine; enhances GABA effects at the receptor complex.
